11:19 am
BE

Basically marks to market, but phrases it as "What if current metals prices hold?"

BE

For most of 2016, underlying prices of some of the key bulk commodities and
base metals have proven extremely resilient, particularly iron ore, with prices
continuing to increase thus far in April. While the BMO Commodities
Research team continues to expect most underlying prices to moderate during
the course of 2016, the reality is it hasn’t happened yet, and the magnitude
and pace of the underlying price increases thus far raise the spectre of upward
estimate revisions in a sector dominated by downward estimate revisions for
the majority of the previous four years.

BE

General Observations: 1) On average, we estimate the global diversified
miners are trading at ~7.6x and 6.2x 2016E/2017E EBITDA if current
prices/currencies remain in place, still reasonable EV/EBITDA multiples for
this group. There is a noticeable difference between the low and the high, with
Rio Tinto and Anglo American trading below 5.0x 2017E EBITDA, while
Teck is trading above 8.5x 2017E EBITDA. 2) On average, we estimate 2016
and 2017 EBITDA estimates for these companies have 14% and 21% upside
on average versus our current estimates. 3) Among the individual equities, we
estimate that Rio Tinto has the most significant EBITDA upside potential
versus our current estimates (+29% in 2016 and +57% in 2017), and also
trades toward the lower end of the EV/EBITDA multiples for the group based
on spot prices (5.7x 2016 and 4.6x 2017), driven primarily by the higher iron
ore prices thus far in 2016. Conversely, both Vale’s and Teck’s leverage to
higher iron ore and met coal/copper/zinc prices, respectively, while still
significant, are somewhat muted by recent sharp appreciation in the Brazilian
real and Canadian dollar, respectively. Among global diversified miners, we
maintain our preference for Rio Tinto, due to the combination of a) relative
balance sheet strength; b) favorable cost curve position; and c) upward
estimate revision potential/and attractive valuation at spot commodity prices.

11:27 am
PM

I'll spare you the central bankers are morons drop in intro

PM

One example where I find market participants have totally swallowed the policy-makers
mantra is that the solution to the UK housing shortage is to build more houses. This
propaganda has been repeated so much that it is has become the 100% accepted truth.
Indeed it would have escaped nobody’s attention that UK house prices have been booming
and are at nose-bleed levels of expense on simple price/earnings measures.

PM

The chart above is from the excellent interactive service from The Economist. I have posted
just a few selected countries but you can play around with it here. It is notable the UK house
price bubble in the mid-naughties never properly corrected during the bust, unlike the US. The
only country where house prices performed even better than the UK since 2008 is Canada.
This unsurpassed record of house price bubble blowing occurred while none other than Mark
Carney was at the top of the Bank of Canada. Given the belief of UK politicians that strong
house prises is a essential to re-election and given Carney’s track record, no wonder UK
Chancellor George Osborne sought him out to be the Bank of England Governor. I mused at
the time if Carney could be bubble-blower extraordinaire, Alan Greenspan, in disguise link.

11:27 am
BE

Hm. Imagine if Albert were invited onto the MPC. How would markets react?

PM

Economist intereact here btw http://www.economi...lobal-house-prices

PM

Carney has indeed presided over a rapid acceleration of UK house prices during his tenure.
The Economist shows that UK house prices have been the strongest in the developed world
since he was appointed. No accident surely? And it is also no accident that if you are a first
time buyer in London you now have to borrow 10x your gross income to buy a house!

11:28 am
PM

To be fair London has its issues with foreign investors using the housing stock as a
destination for capital flight, but let that excuse not deflect you from the simple truth that
unprecedented loose UK money has driven prices to ridiculous levels, a development
welcomed by the policy makers indeed that is the purpose of QE. So what do they do in
response? The government puts in place taxpayer subsidised mortgages to first time buyers
to put them even more in debt! We have called this policy what it is moronic, see link.
W

PM

We are told that the only remedy for the unaffordability of housing is more supply. There must
surely be a shortage of housing and we need to build more. Every paper and commentator is
full of it. Andy Haldane a leading policy maker just reaffirmed it too “There are things we can
do at the bank and others can do at the Treasury to damp down demand a bit, but ultimately
the solution to the problem lies in the supply side rather than constraining demand.” – link.
Total and utter tosh! Isn’t it curious by the way that whenever house prices are falling they
must stimulate demand and whenever prices are too strong they call for more supply never
the reverse! (There are of course vested interests who gain greatly from repeating and
perpetuating the lie that more supply is the solution to the UK’s housing problems.)

PM

I’m sorry, but if monetary policy is too loose, you can concrete over the entire length and
breadth of the UK and house prices would still rise. There is no shortage of housing. What
there is, is an imbalance between demand and supply and demand is excessive because
of crazily loose monetary policy. It’s as simple as that. And, as the most prescient guys at
Fathom Consulting have pointed out, if there really is a shortage of houses, surely rents,
like house prices, would be rising too, way in excess of other prices in the UK economy?
But the answer is that over the last ten years they have not (see chart below as you can see
weak oil prices have held down overall CPI, allowing rents to catch up recently). The lesson
here is not to believe what the lies and half-truths policy makers are peddling us (that’s global
not just the UK). Central Bankers are surely taking us down the road to perdition.

BE

But why am I paraphrasing? He can explain himself.

11:34 am
BE

We turned cautious on the sector in November 2015 as we were concerned that the sector’s valuation was too stretched to accommodate margin pressure that we could see building. We feared that house price inflation would slow and high build cost inflation persist, so that margins would peak in 2016. The sector has underperformed since then, even if it has not been for exactly the reasons we identified.

BE

Housebuilders’ shares are now down 17% (absolute) since the peak (29 December) and 13% since our November note. They have underperformed the overall market by 7% in Q1 2016, which is only the 4th time in 23 years that they have underperformed in Q1.

BE

In terms of the risks being priced in .........

11:35 am
BE

• EU Referendum: the most likely scenario is Remain, but there are risks to the sector if a Leave decision leads to slower GDP growth and rising rates.
• Prime London ripple: weakness in prime London is not a concern in its own right, the more important question is whether weakness ripples out to the rest of London and the UK. We think it is most likely that it will not, but a Leave vote may be a catalyst for a ripple effect to materialise.
• Margin pressure: we are still convinced that affordability is a constraint to house price inflation, especially if the FPC further restricts mortgage lending standards, and we believe that slowing buy-to-let activity will cool the whole market. We also believe that labour cost inflation will not recede and material cost inflation will return.
• Deflation: an environment of falling prices (CPI or RPI) would be tough for housebuilders, but the chances of this appear remote, in our view.

BE

And on a stock specific view ..........

BE

We see little downside left in the sector after its recent underperformance. We have upgraded Persimmon and Barratt from Sell to Hold and Redrow from Hold to Buy. Our top picks are Bellway (Buy) and Gleeson (Buy), and our only Sell is now Taylor Wimpey. The stock market has sold off companies which are most exposed to more discretionary housing markets, as well as Redrow for its relative indebtedness. Our top picks for a Remain bounce are Berkeley and Barratt.

11:41 am
BE

Awful risky buying the next deal.

Melrose Industries PLC (MRO:LSE): Last: 377.00, down 14.9 (-3.80%), High: 394.90, Low: 375.00, Volume: 786.17k
BE

Current premium high enough and could dilute future returns. Melrose shares
trade at a 20% premium to our sum-of-the-parts valuation, the key metric given
the managements buy/improve/sell strategy. This premium reflects investors appetite
to participate in the next deal, driven by the strong management track record for
generating value (average shareholder return 22% pa since the first deal in 2005,
source Melrose accounts). This premium suggests a c.£100m management premium
or valuation gap. At the same time we see less potential for value creation in the
current operations, primarily Brush, given the actions already undertaken which could
also impinge on future returns. Any deal will have to subsidise this valuation gap. In a
smaller deal this could be material, we estimate potentially halving IRR on a transaction
of similar value to Melrose today. In a larger deal the impact will be reduced but there
is also less likely to be a requirement to hold shares for pre-emption rights given the
scale of the associated fund raising on a major transaction. Given this premium and
the inevitable lack of clarity on any deal at present we see no reason to chase the
shares and prefer to wait until there is clarity on the next transaction. Hence our move
from Buy to Hold.

11:48 am
BE

Anyway, sector piece from Deutsche. I'll start at the top.

BE

Share prices in the sector increased 8% on average in Q1, compared to a 3%
decrease for the market (MSCI Europe). UK food retailers in particular had a
strong run, mostly reflecting market relative multiple expansion but also
slightly better relative consensus ‚NTM‛ (next twelve month) EPS growth
versus the market. On 4 April we downgraded Tesco from Buy to Hold. In this
note, we downgrade Morrisons from Hold to Sell. This morning in a separate
note, we upgraded Sainsbury’s from Hold to Buy.
UK names had a very strong performance but Continentals also outperformed.
The 11% outperformance of the sector vs. the market in Q1 reflected an
average 27% outperformance by the UK food retailers and an average 6%
outperformance by the Continental European food retailers. The UK
outperformance was dominated by Morrisons (+38%) and Tesco (+33%).
Jeronimo Martins and Casino had the strongest performances among the
Continental European names, outperforming 24% and 23% respectively.
Sector Q2 performance to date has been broadly in line with the market,
although the UK names have pulled back a little while the Continental
Europeans (particularly Metro and Carrefour) have outperformed.

BE

PE has its limitations but we continue to view it as relevant at sector level.
After a strong performance in Q1, the sector is now trading on 17x PE, 11%
above its 25 year average. This looks expensive, although we note it is on a
1.12x market relative PE, only slightly above its 25 year average. Earnings
have still not stabilized, although EPS downgrades were less than for the
market. At stock level, we focus on sustainable free cash flow and SOTP,
which can lead to different views on valuation. Nonetheless, we see PE as a
relevant metric. On this basis, we see limited absolute upside at sector level
but potential to outperform in a declining market.
Downgrading Morrisons from Hold to Sell.
We downgrade Morrisons from Hold to Sell, leaving our DCF based PT
unchanged at 175p, representing 9% downside. Morrisons was the top
performer in Q1, outperforming the market by 38%. Given Morrisons’
customer overlap with Asda, we expect it to be most impacted by increased
price competition in the market. Morrisons will report Q1 trading for 13 weeks
to 1 May on Thursday 5 May. We forecast a +0.4% LFL vs. +0.1% in Q4.

11:49 am
WM Morrison Supermarkets PLC (MRW:LSE): Last: 192.70, up 1.5 (+0.78%), High: 193.80, Low: 189.20, Volume: 4.42m
BE

And on a Sainsbury view, they've had another think about Argos and now reckon it's actually pretty positive.

BE

(A view we've had here for a while, FWIW.)

11:50 am
BE

In our view, investors
are reluctant to factor in this earnings accretion due to execution risk. We also
show that Sainsbury’s has achieved the greatest reduction in the level of
promotions of the Big 4, over the past 18 months. We think this can contribute
to a better margin trend. On 13x cons. 16/17 PE, Sainsbury’s share price
already reflects downside risk to near term earnings. In combination with a
c.3.5% dividend yield, we see 15% return potential. With risk/reward skewed to
the upside, we upgrade from Hold to Buy.

BE

Expect pressures on underlying grocery – remain below consensus ex Argos.
Our unchanged 16/17 EPS forecast is c.20% below consensus. Without
integrating Argos, our outer year numbers would also be materially below
consensus. However, we think this is already reflected in a 16/17 PE of 13x vs.
28x at Tesco and 18x at Morrisons (based on consensus). As such, we expect
consensus to come down post full year results on Wed 4th May.
But expect Argos acquisition to be 25% accretive in 2018E.
We forecast the Argos acquisition to generate 4.5p additional EPS, 20% on
consensus 18/19 22.4p and 25% on below consensus DBe 18/19 18.2p.
We think a less promotional strategy is supporting Sainsbury’s margin.
Sainsbury’s is the only one of the Big 4 to have materially reduced promotional
participation over the past 18 months, lowering the give-away by c.2%. See
inside for detailed analysis on retailer promotional activity over the past year.
Upgrade to Buy based on Argos accretion and differentiated promo strategy.
We base our 325p PT on a DCF, using a normalised 2.6% EBIT margin, 2.9%
capex/sales, a terminal growth rate of 0% and a WACC of 6.5%. Downside
risks include competition issues related to HRG bid, the execution risks of
Argos integration if the take-over is successful, market share loss to Lidl and
lower than expected profit due to negative operating leverage or price
investment. We think Tesco may take the lead on price investment, preempting
competitive action from Asda, however we feel we have factored this
into our forecasts with a 0.5% yoy margin decline in 16/17.

BE

Price target goes from 265p to 325p.

11:51 am
undefined
BE

And just finally on the sellside wrap ...........

Ted Baker PLC (TED:LSE): Last: 2,380, up 109.67 (+4.83%), High: 2,382, Low: 2,244, Volume: 188.21k
11:51 am
BE

.... which has been absolutely smashed since Michael Stewart of Panmure stuck out a sell note.

BE

April 12th, I think that was.

BE

Details here: http://ftalphavill...tslive/2016-04-12/

11:52 am
BE

Today, Liberum's pulled together some counterpoints.

BE

In a challenging environment we believe that Ted will outperform its
peers given the strength of the brand and the channels to market.
Despite a tough market in H2 2015 for luxury goods and retail Ted
performed well with Retail sales growth of 8% and total sales growth of
12%.

BE

• A balanced business: retail, wholesale, licensing and online - Ted is
developing a well-balanced business with multiple routes to market. Retail,
Wholesale and Licencing are complemented by an increasingly important
online business which brings the brand to a wider audience without
necessarily needing to roll out new stores. Online reached 15% of group
Retail sales last year, and 19% of UK and Europe Retail sales. Licensing
revenues grew by 23% to £14.4m, 24% of Group EBIT.
• Sales densities and market misconception - Ted’s sales densities
slowed in H2 2015 impacted by a tough trading environment, unseasonal
weather patterns and the terror attacks in Paris which saw fewer shoppers
on the High Street and a reduction in tourist traffic. Our analysis of Ted’s
sales patterns over the past year shows two things: that there has been a
continued channel shift with trade moving online, which we believe is
margin accretive; and that there is a misconception in the market that
sales densities are a direct proxy for LFL sales. In our view the timing of
store openings can be a negative drag on sales density metrics while LFL
sales growth at peers is flattered in relative terms by excluding immature
space.
• Low exposure to China and strong in US Wholesale - While the retail
sector saw a slowdown in growth in H2 2015 the tide has turned more
sharply for the luxury goods sector as seen in profit warnings from
Burberry and Hugo Boss. As an international brand we find that, in the
minds of some investors, Ted’s fortunes may be similarly under pressure.
We believe that this is the wrong interpretation. Ted’s exposure to China is
minimal at c2% of sales. Its US wholesale business is strong and
performing substantially better than peers. The company’s pricing
architecture, with product prices comfortably below Ralph Lauren and
Hugo Boss, as well as pricing integrity with low promotional participation,
supports demand for full price sales.
• Cash flow metrics improving & appropriate for early stage growth – In
response to investor’s concerns we find that Ted’s FCF yield, while low
against the SMID Luxury and Branded goods average, is entirely
appropriate for a company still early in its development relative to some of
its peers. In addition to FCF yield, measuring value, we track FCF/EBITDA
as a performance measure vs the sector. Figure 1 and Figure 2 show that
while Ted is low on this measure in the current year the gap begins to
close by 2018 as capex eases.

11:53 am
BE

Clearly cash flow is limited at this stage of its growth curve with positive
working capital and a relatively high capex/sales ratio. Ted has grown fast
in the US, from £9m of sales in 2007 to £81m last year and we believe that
sales could double from here in four to five years. The Asian business
remains nascent with £15m sales last year and there remains plenty of
scope for growth in continental Europe so investment in stores will remain
a part of the equation, although as online takes an increasingly important
role in driving sales growth we forecast a decline in capex/sales.
• Valuation – We maintain our BUY rating on Ted but cut our target price
from 3700p to 3100p in part due to peer group de-rating. In addition we
adjust our DCF for a beta of 0.8, from 0.7 to reflect increased volatility in
the share price. Ted’s three year forward EPS CAGR of 13% sits towards
the top end of the peer group range. The sector is on 8% implying a
substantial growth premium for Ted.

BE

So .......... Take your pick. Ted Baker is one of those brands that feels like a foreign country to me.

BE

Not sure why anyone would buy it unless it's unexpectedly cheap.

PM

Here's a par from UBS

PM

Volkswagen likely to announce total provisions on Friday
Volkswagen is expected to announce key figures for 2015 on Friday after the board meeting, including all provisions related to the Diesel issue (incl. a potential criminal fine). If the total amount remains below the upper limit of €20bn reported by Reuters, it would be well below what we believe consensus expectations were, and also clearly less than the €31bn we modelled for the aforementioned items. Every €5bn deviation from market expectations is worth €10/share (assuming no tax deductibility). Furthermore, we believe the pending US agreement made the stock a difficult investment for many institutions. With today's announcement, we think investors could now revisit the stock.

11:59 am
PM

What's next? Further potential positive catalysts ahead
With the agreement in principle completed, Volkswagen can now focus on improving the low profitability of the VW car brand. We expect first details on next week's results conference (28 April), and visibility should further improve with the upcoming strategic review in summer. While we believe the 6% margin target for VW cars in 2018 is overly ambitious, we expect the company to confirm the target.
Valuation: €160 price target is SOTP-based
Our €160 PT is based on a SOTP model with target multiples for each division, based on 2016E. This means that any margin recovery of VW cars in the coming years is not reflected in our target. If we apply the current average 7.5x PE 2017E of Renault/Peugeot on VW and subtract the speculated €20bn (€40/share) diesel issue cost, the fair value would be c€150/share.
